I thrive in collaborative environments and enjoy solving complex problems to deliver high-quality solutions. I canâ€™t remember having a goal. An actual goal. There are things Iâ€™ve wanted to do, but if I didnâ€™t do them Iâ€™d be fine with that too. There are targets that would have been nice to hit, but if I didnâ€™t hit them I wouldnâ€™t look back and say I missed them. I donâ€™t aim for things that way. I do things, I try things, I build things, I want to make progress, I want to make things better for me, my company, my family, my neighborhood, etc. But Iâ€™ve never set a goal. Itâ€™s just not how I approach things.
A goal is something that goes away when you hit it. Once youâ€™ve reached it, itâ€™s gone. You could always set another one, but I just donâ€™t function in steps like that. When you shift from 1st to 2nd, 1st is behind you. Then from 2nd to 3rd, 2nd is behind you. I approach things continuously, not in stops. I just want to keep going â€” whatever happens along the way is just what happens. I consider Basecamp, my current business, as one continuous line back from when I sold the first thing I ever remember making â€” a logo for $50 (which happened to be for Andrei Heramischukâ€” who knew!). I was 16 or something like that at the time. I didnâ€™t have a goal to make two logos, or to be able to charge $5000 for a logo. I just made logos. And then I made software. And then I made web sites. And now I make software again. No goals in the process that I remember. I just worked at whatever I was working on and ended up wherever I am. I continue to approach work and life that same way today. If Iâ€™ve used the word goal, I didnâ€™t mean it that way. It was just the word I picked, a synonym for something else. I really like what Jim Coudal said about goals: â€œThe reason that most of us are unhappy most of the time is that we set our goals not for the person weâ€™re going to be when we reach them, but we set our goals for the person we are when we set them. That pretty much sums it up for me.

Why choose Obsidian # Local Storage & Privacy
â€¢	Obsidian stores all your notes as plain text Markdown files on your local machine. This means your data is entirely in your control, with no dependence on cloud services unless you choose to sync it yourself. â€¢	It offers privacy by default, as none of your data is shared with external servers unless explicitly set up.
Markdown-Based
â€¢	Obsidian uses the Markdown format, which is lightweight and widely supported. Itâ€™s a simple, human-readable format that can easily be exported, transferred, or integrated with other platforms. â€¢	Markdown files also mean that your notes are future-proof â€” youâ€™re not locked into proprietary formats.
Bidirectional Linking
â€¢	One of Obsidianâ€™s most powerful features is its bidirectional linking. You can easily link notes together, and see all notes that link back to the current note, helping you create a network of interrelated ideas. â€¢	This creates a knowledge graph that helps surface connections between ideas, fostering serendipitous discovery of related content.
Graph View
â€¢	The graph view provides a visual representation of your notes and their connections. You can see how ideas are linked together in real-time, making it easier to explore relationships between your notes. â€¢	This can be especially useful for researchers, students, or anyone managing complex topics, as it turns your notes into a dynamic mind map.
Highly Customizable
â€¢	Obsidian offers a variety of themes, plugins, and community add-ons that allow you to tailor the tool to your exact needs. Whether itâ€™s customizing your writing environment or adding new functionalities, Obsidian is highly extendable. â€¢	You can install plugins for features like task management, flashcards, calendar integration, or even integrate with code snippets for programming tasks.
Offline-First
â€¢	Since Obsidian works with local files, you donâ€™t need an internet connection to access or manage your notes. Everything is available offline, making it perfect for writing and note-taking in areas with limited connectivity.
Speed and Efficiency
â€¢	Obsidian is lightweight and fast, able to handle large collections of notes without slowing down. Itâ€™s a performance-oriented tool designed to scale well with your growing knowledge base. â€¢	With the help of hotkeys and a command palette, users can easily navigate through notes and perform actions quickly.
Community Support
â€¢	Obsidian has an active and thriving community that develops plugins, creates tutorials, and shares best practices for personal knowledge management. Youâ€™ll find lots of community-generated resources to help you get more from the app.
Cross-Platform Availability
â€¢	Obsidian runs on Windows, macOS, Linux, Android, and iOS, meaning you can access your notes across devices seamlessly. Obsidian Sync (optional paid service) provides encrypted synchronization between devices for users who want automatic backups and cross-device sync.
Non-Linear Organization
â€¢	Unlike linear or folder-based systems, Obsidian encourages non-linear note-taking. Itâ€™s easy to create connections between notes in any direction, making it ideal for complex, interrelated ideas like research, journaling, or long-term knowledge development.
Free for Personal Use
â€¢	Obsidian is free for personal use, making it accessible to a broad audience. Paid features like Obsidian Sync or Obsidian Publish are optional and suited for users with specific needs like cloud synchronization or web publishing.
